data.title: Manchester museums guide: All the addresses, numbers, prices and what's on information you need
data.meta_description: We've pulled together all the vital information you could want about the museums you and the family will love
data.text:
Manchester and the surrounding area is chock full of fun and fascinating museums that keep kids of all ages - and adults for that matter - enthralled and entertained.

We’ve pulled together this list of museums that you can visit, with address details and opening times.

If there are any on your radar that you think we’ve missed, then drop us a line through Facebook or Twitter and we’ll check them out.

In the meantime - here’s our list of museums around Greater Manchester.

Natural History

Manchester Museum

Address: Oxford Rd, Manchester, M13 9PL

Phone/Website: 0161 275 2634 / manchester.ac.uk/museum

What’s On: The museum houses permanent collections of taxidermy, pottery, jewellery and Egyptian mummies.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day

Price: Free

The Whitaker

Address: Whitaker Park, Haslingden Rd, Rawtenstall, BB4 6RE

Phone/Website: 01706 260785 / thewhitaker.org

What's On: A museum and art gallery, The Whitaker houses a permanent collection of curious Victorian natural history artifacts - some of them posed in the most unlikely positions.

Opening Hours: Tue-Sun, 10am-4pm

Price: Free

Conflict & Military History

Imperial War Museum North

Address: Trafford Wharf Rd, Salford Quays, M17 1TZ

Phone/Website: 0161 836 4000 / iwm.org.uk

What’s On: Accompanying the museum's extensive timeline of the conflicts that have affected Britain and the Commonwealth is Horrible Histories Blitzed Brits, featuring over 200 objects that tell the personal stories of people who lived through the First World War ‘Blitz’.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day

Price: Free

Dunham Massey

Address: Altrincham, WA14 4SJ

Phone/Website: 0161 941 1025 / nationaltrust.org.uk/dunham-massey

What’s On: Acres of space and piles of historic buildings with activities and events on daily.

Opening Hours: 11am-5pm every day

Price: £12 adults, £6 children

The Fusilier Museum

Address: Moss Street, Bury, BL9 0DF

Phone/Website: 0161 763 8950 / fusiliermuseum.com

What’s On: The story of one of Lancashire’s most famous regiments, including the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day - note: no parking on site.

Price: £3.95 adults, £2.95 children and concessions (allows 12 months access)

Stockport Air Raid Shelters

Address: 61 Chestergate, Stockport SK1 1NE

Phone/Website: 0161 474 1940 / stockport.gov.uk/airraidshelters

What’s On: Visitors can explore a mile of tunnels that offered shelter to 6,500 Stockport people during the wars and find out what life was like for them above ground.

Opening Hours: Tue-Fri, 1pm-5pm; Sat, 10am-5pm; Sun, 11am- 5pm (open Bank Holiday Mondays only)

Price: £4.75, under-16s free with adult, £3.50 concessions including guided tour (accepts £12.50 Stockport multi-site pass)

Manchester Regiment Museum

Address: Ashton Town Hall, Market Place, OL6 6DL

Phone/Website: 0161 343 2878 / tameside.gov.uk/museumsgalleries/mom

What’s On: The story of regimental life since 1756 to today.

Opening Hours: Tue-Fri, 10am-4pm; Sat 10am-1pm (closed until Summer 2016)

Price: Free

Science & Industry

Museum of Science & Industry

Address: Liverpool Rd, Manchester M3 4FP

Phone/Website: 0161 832 2244 / mosi.org.uk

What’s On: Regular temporary exhibitions sit alongside permanent galleries boast machinery from industry, motoring, air travel and the railways.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day

Price: Free, some visiting events may have entrance fees

Anson Engine Museum

Address: Anson Rd, Poynton, SK12 1TD

Phone/Website: 01625 874426 / enginemuseum.org

What’s On: The museum runs steam engines every day.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day

Price: £6.75 adults, £2.50 age 13-16, under-12 free, £6.25 concessions

Transport Museum

Address: Boyle Street, Cheetham, M8 8UW

Phone/Website: 0161 205 2122 / gmts.co.uk

What’s On: Among the highlights in the collection are the largest Victorian open-top horse drawn bus in existence, the last rear-loader double decker bus built, and the bus station tea room.

Opening Hours: Every day in August, 10am-4.30pm, then Wed/Sat/Sun and Bank Holidays.

Price: £4 adults, free under-16, £2 concessions

Astley Green Colliery Museum

Address: Higher Green Ln, Tyldesley M29 7JB

Phone/Website: 01942 708969 / agcm.org.uk

What’s On: Lancashire’s only remaining colliery houses the only surviving headgear and engine house, now listed, as well as 28 colliery locomotives on it 15 acre site.

Opening Hours: Sun/Tue/Thu, 1.30pm-5.00pm

Price: £1

Quarry Bank Mill

Address: Styal, Wilmslow, SK9 4LA

Phone/Website: 01625 527468 / nationaltrust.org.uk/quarry-bank

What’s On: Easily offering one of the fullest explorations of how people lived and worked during the Industrial Revolution, this cotton mill, built in 1784, has fully working machinery powered by a working waterwheel, as well as a home for pauper children, extensive gardens, a forest, and some visiting exhibitions.

Opening Hours: 10.30am-5pm daily (check website for closures)

Price: £14.40 adult, £7.20 children

Architecture

Staircase House

Address: 30/31 Market Pl, Stockport SK1 1ES

Phone/Website: 0161 218 1460 / stockport.gov.uk/staircasehouse

What’s On: The 15th century house, famous for its rare Jacobean cage-newel staircase.

Opening Hours: Tue-Fri, 1pm-5pm; Sat, 10am-5pm; Sun, 11am- 5pm (open Bank Holiday Mondays only)

Price: £4.75, under-16s free with adult, £3.50 concessions including guided tour (accepts £12.50 Stockport multi-site pass)

Tatton Old Hall

Address: Knutsford, WA16 6QN

Phone/Website: 01625 374400 / tattonpark.org.uk

What’s On: Part of the National Park’s Tatton Park estate, Tatton Hall can be explored with costumed guides, who lead an evocative journey through its history as a dwelling place - from manor house to humble cottages.

Opening Hours: August 13/14/20/21/27/28, 12pm-4pm (tours on the hour)

Price: £6 adults, £4 children (4-15 years)

Bramall Hall

Address: Hall Rd, Bramhall, SK7 3NX

Phone/Website: 0161 474 2020 / stockport.gov.uk/bramallhall

What’s On: If you’ve never seen Bramall Hall, prepared to be astonished. There’s nothing quite like it, and the whole house can be explored, from kitchens to bedrooms.

Opening Hours: Closed until 2016 (included here for completeness)

Price: £4.75, under-16s free with adult, £3.50 concessions including guided tour (accepts £12.50 Stockport multi-site pass)

Manchester Jewish Museum

Address: 190 Cheetham Hill Rd, M8 8LW

Phone/Website: 0161 834 9879 / manchesterjewishmuseum.com

What’s On: Located in a former Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue on Cheetham Hill Road, this is the only Jewish Museum outside London and is housed in the oldest surviving synagogue building in Manchester - completed in 1874 in Moorish style with exquisite stained glass windows and cast-iron fitments.

Opening Hours: Sun-Thu, 10am-4pm; Fri, 10am-1pm

Price: £4.50 adults, £3.50 concessions (includes guide tour and exhibitions)

Ordsall Hall

Address: 322 Ordsall Lane, Ordsall, M5 3AN

Phone/Website: 0161 872 0251 / salfordcommunityleisure.co.uk/culture/ordsall-hall

What’s On: Positioned on the edge of Ordsall and Salford Quays in considerable grounds, the house is fully restored and beautifully cared for, with regular visiting exhibitions from artists.

Opening Hours: Mon-Thu, 10am-4pm; Sun 1pm-4pm

Price: Free, parking charges of £2 (three hours) and £5 (over three hours) apply

Sports

National Football Museum

Address: Cathedral Gardens, Manchester, M4 3BG

Phone/Website: 0161 605 8200 / nationalfootballmuseum.com

What’s On: The museum operates a series of family friendly events, too, including Skills Sunday and face painting events. There are also regularly changing exhibitions.

Opening Hours: Mon-Sat, 10am-5pm; Sun, 11am-5pm

Price: Free

Social History

People’s History Museum

Address: Left Bank, Manchester, M3 3ER

Phone/Website: 0161 838 9190 / phm.org.uk

What’s On: On every floor it tells the tale of popular struggle for democracy through two centuries of banners and artefacts. Regular temporary exhibitions also feature.

Opening Hours: 10am-5pm every day

Price: Free

Working Class Movement Library

Address: 51 Crescent, Salford, M5 4WX

Phone/Website: 0161 736 3601 / www.wcml.org.uk

What’s On: One of the most unusual libraries in the world. Discover the stories of working people’s struggles to be heard.

Opening Hours: Tue-Fri, 10am-5pm; first Saturday of every month, 10am-4pm

Price: Free

Manchester Police Museum

Address: 57A Newton St, Manchester M1 1ET

Phone/Website: 0161 856 4500 / gmpmuseum.co.uk

What’s On: Tales of Manchester’s criminal past and its original Victorian charge office make the museum fascinating.

Opening Hours: Tue, 10.30am-3.30pm.

Price: Free

Salford Museum & Art Gallery

Address: Peel Park, Crescent, M5 4WU

Phone/Website: 0161 778 0800 / salfordcommunityleisure.co.uk/culture/salford-museum-and-art-gallery

What’s On: Ticking two bills as a museum and gallery, Salford’s red brick building commits great space to looking at social history, plus there’s its street, Lark Hill Place.

Opening Hours: Tue-Fri, 10am-4.45pm; Sat-Sun, 12pm-4pm

Price: Free

Culture

Chetham’s Library

Address: Chetham’s Library, Long Millgate, M3 1SB

Phone/Website: 0161 834 7961 / www.chethams.org.uk

What’s On: Chetham’s School of Music houses one of the greatest architectural gems in Manchester - a 17th century library, the oldest public library in the English-speaking world, where Marx and Engels created the Communist Manifesto. The books that inspired them are still in the collection.

Opening Hours: Mon-Fri, 9am-12.30pm and 1.30pm-4.30pm. Visitors must be accompanied on site, book in advance or enquire at the security lodge on arrival.

Price: Free

Elizabeth Gaskell House

Address: 84 Plymouth Grove, M13 9LW

Phone/Website: 0161 273 2215 / elizabethgaskellhouse.co.uk

What's On: Lovingly restored thanks to the commitment of volunteers and £2.5m of donations (including money from the Heritage Lottery Fund), Elizabeth Gaskell's Grade II listed mansion house is a faithful representation of what the property would have looked like during her 15 years there from 1850 to 1865. Visitors can settle down on the sofas, look at books in the library, read about her famous visitors (including Charlotte Bronte) and walk around the substantial gardens - as well as take a spot of tea and cake in the dining room.

Opening Hours: Wed, Thu & Sun, 11.00am-4.30pm (last entry 4.00pm)

Price: £4.95 adults, £3.95 concessions, unde-16s free with an adult.

Portico Library

Address: 57 Mosley St, Manchester, M2 3HY

Phone/Website: 0161 236 6785 / theportico.org.uk

What’s On: A changing show of exhibitions sits in the central reading room, but the real star is the library itself which houses a collection of books under its stained glass dome ceiling leafed through by the likes of Charles Dickens and (out of hours, at this once gentleman only library) Elizabeth Gaskell. Stop for light lunch, from 12pm-2pm, or Saturday tea and cake from 11am-3pm.

Opening Hours: Mon-Fri, 9.30-5.30 (4.30 Mon & Fri); Sat 11am-5pm

Price: Free

Fashion

Gallery of Costume

Address: Platt Hall, Platt Fields Park, M14 5LL

Phone/Website: 0161 245 7245 / manchesterartgallery.org/visit/gallery-of-costume

What’s On: Permanent collection of historic and iconic fashion.

Opening Hours: Thu- Fri, 1pm-5pm; Sat-Sunday 10am-5pm

Price: Free

Hat Works

Address: Wellington Mill, Stockport SK3 0EU

Phone/Website: 0161 474 2399 / stockport.gov.uk/hatworks

What’s On: A recreation of a hat factory with 20 restored and working Victorian-style machines and 400 hats on show. The museum has two visiting exhibitions per year.

Opening Hours: Tue-Sat, 10am - 5pm; Sun, 11am-5pm (closed Mon)
